variantrule.name: Downtime Activity: Crafting
entries: If you have access to a blueprint or have a relevant tool proficiency, you may craft an item during downtime.

entries.name: Resources
entries: The process of crafting an item can vary from item to item, which is determined by the rarity of the item and the crafters proficiency with the tools to craft it.
When crafting, the outcome of a days worth of work is determined as follows:

entries.text: {@dice d8} + relevant tool or skill proficiency bonus + progress - difficulty

entries: The outcomes on specific rolls are listed below.
On completion, you pay the cost of the item in either resources or gold (usually half the original price).

entries.name: Difficulty
entries: Below is a table specifying the difficulty to craft an item based on rarity.

entries.name: Complications
entries: Complications usually arise when you gain the Status Quo effect on the crafting check. Roll on the table below to see what effects happen.

entries.caption: Crafting Complications
rows: You must start over, causing you to lose all current {@i progress}.
You must pay half the cost of crafting the item in gold or resources that day, having failed or wanting to redo a certain part.
You must pay quarter of the cost of crafting the item in gold or resources that day, trying various ways to craft the item.

feat.name: Infernal Attunement
entries: Attuning more into your infernal heritage, you evolve into a form capable of doing great things. With that, you gain the benefits as listed below:

items: Choose one of the following:

Your body grows new tools at your disposal, similar to the fiend you are related to. You gain a new natural weapon, which deals {@damage 1d6} + your Strength modifier slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage, as appropriate for the appendage(s) created or upgraded by this feat. In case of gaining new limbs, you can make them appear and dissapear as a bonus action.
Your connection to the depths of hell grows stronger. Pick a 2nd-level spell from the Warlock spell list. You can cast this spell once per long rest.

You can manifest your rage as a beam of brimstone darkness. When you take the {@action Attack} action, you can replace one of your attacks with shooting a beam of brimstone out of your mouth. The laser is a 5 feet wide, 30-foot line that damages anyone and anything in its path. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. A creature takes {@dice 2d6} radiant damage on a failed save, or half that on a success.

feat.name: Infernal Wings
entries: Your infernal heritage owns wings, and now whether suddenly, through arcane experimentation, or drinking fiendish blood, you have them too.

items: You grow bat wings from your back, those giving you a flight speed of 30 feet. You can make them appear and dissapear as a bonus action.

subclass.name: Hand of Dread
subclassFeatures: Deal with the Devil|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Hand of Dread|SterlingVermin|6

subclass.name: The Sweet Science
subclassFeatures: Float Like a Butterfly, Sting Like a Bee|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Sweet Science|SterlingVermin|11

subclass.name: Whiskey Fist
subclassFeatures: Minotaur in a Glassworker's Shop|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Whiskey Fist|SterlingVermin:Patreon|17

subclass.name: King of Beasts
subclassFeatures: Cornered but Not Caught|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|King of Beasts|SterlingVermin:Patreon|11

subclass.name: Giant Soul (UA)
subclassFeatures: Blessing of the All Father|Sorcerer||Giant Soul (UA)|UAGiantSoulSorcerer|18

subclassFeature.name: Arena Royale
entries: Pugilists in the Arena Royale fight club travel the world earning their keep as equal parts performer and gladiator. Whether performing in staged physical competitions, or fighting it out in unscripted brawls, pugilists in the Arena Royale care as much about the theatrics of a fight as they do its outcome. Pugilists in this fight club also care deeply about their reputation and work to build up local and regional legends about their performing personas.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: Starting when you choose this Fight Club at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance} skill, if you don't have it already. If you do, you gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Persona Libre
entries: Also at 3rd level, you create an alternate persona that you can adopt or discard as a bonus action on your turn. When you create an alternate persona you should give the persona a striking name as well as some physical signifier (such as a mask, colorful cape, or another prominent idiosyncratic feature). Unless you tell a creature, or the creature sees you adopt your persona, they do not know you and the adopted persona are the same person.

Additionally, you have a pool of persona points equal to 3 + your Charisma modifier (minimum 1). When you use an ability that costs moxie points, you can spend persona points instead. In addition, before you make a Charisma ability check you can spend a persona point to add your Strength modifier to the result. You can only use persona points while you have adopted your persona. You regain all expended persona points when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Work the Crowd
entries: At 6th level, while you have adopted your alternate persona, you can use your action to inspire your choice of fear or adoration in those nearby. When you do, all creatures within 30 feet who can see you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be {@condition charmed}, if you chose adoration, or {@condition frightened} if you chose fear. This effect lasts for one minute. Each time a creature takes damage from you or one of your allies it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success. You can use this feature again after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: High Flyer
entries: Starting at 11th level, your base movement increases by 10 feet, your jump distance is doubled, and you can use a bonus action on your turn to take the {@action Dash} action.

subclassFeature.name: Signature Move
entries: Starting at 17th level, you create a signature move that you can use while you have adopted your alternate persona. Give your signature move a name and a description. You can replace one of your unarmed attacks or attacks with a pugilist weapon on your turn with this signature move.

When you use your signature move, you can jump in any direction up to your movement speed, make an attack roll with advantage against a creature in your reach and, if you hit, the attack is a critical and the creature is {@condition stunned} until the end of your next turn.
If you hit with your signature move, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again. If you miss with your signature move, you regain the use of it after 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodhound Bruisers
entries: Pugilists in the Bloodhound Bruisers fight club are notorious for looking for trouble and finding it every time. Members of this fight club are highly observant of character traits and physical evidence and can form an almost supernatural connection to the cities they live in. Most use these abilities to become urban defenders of the downtrodden but others lend their talents to less savory organizations.

subclassFeature.name: Ever Vigilant
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you have advantage on initiative rolls. During the first round of combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures who haven't acted yet.

subclassFeature.name: Detective Work
entries: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with two of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Perception}. In addition, when you make an {@skill Insight} (Wisdom), {@skill Perception} (Wisdom), or {@skill Investigation} (Intelligence) ability check you can spend 1 moxie point to gain advantage on that ability check.

subclassFeature.name: Scrap Like a Sleuth
entries: At 6th level, you can use a bonus action and expend 2 moxie points to hone in on the idiosyncrasies and bad habits of an enemy you can see within 30 feet. When you do, you have advantage on weapon attacks against the creature and you add your proficiency bonus to your AC against attacks made by that creature. These effects continue for 1 minute or until you use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of the City
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you take a long rest in a settlement, you can choose to become familiar with the settlement. When you use this feature again, you replace your previous familiar settlement with the current one. You gain the following benefits while in a familiar settlement:

items: You cannot be surprised and you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative.
You have darkvision to a range of 120 feet.
When you make an ability check using the Insight, Investigation, or Perception skills that adds your proficiency bonus, add twice your proficiency bonus instead.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes Wide Open
entries: Starting at 17th level, you can use a bonus action and spend 1 moxie point to open your senses to your surroundings for 1 minute. During this time, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened} and have truesight out to a distance of 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Dog & Hound
entries: You've never had a friend you could rely on that walked on two legs. Lucky for you, you've got the best fourlegged friend a body could ask for. Pugilists in the Dog & Hound fight club are as faithful to their canine companions as their canine companions are to them.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the {@skill Animal Handling} skill if you don't already have it. If you do, you gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Perception} or {@skill Survival} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Brawler's Best Friend
entries: Also at 3rd level, you gain a hound that accompanies you on your adventures and fights alongside you. Your hound can be any breed of dog or similar canine creature, but uses the statistics of a {@creature wolf}. You add your proficiency bonus to your hound's AC, saving throws, attack rolls, and damage rolls.
For each level you gain after 3rd, your hound gains an additional d8 hit die and increases its hit points accordingly

You can use a bonus action on each of your turns to verbally command your hound to take the Attack, Dash, Disengage, Dodge, or Help action that turn. It does not have its own turn unless you are incapacitated or absent.

If you are incapacitated or absent, the hound acts on its own (continuing to act on your turn, if you are incapacitated), focusing on protecting you and itself. The hound never requires your command to use its reaction, such as when making an opportunity attack.
If your hound dies, you can obtain a new one by spending 8 hours bonding with a canine animal that isn't hostile to you.

subclassFeature.name: Mutt With Moxie
entries: At 3rd level, you share everything with your faithful hound: food, shelter, even moxie. When you use certain moxie abilities, your hound gains a benefit as well.

entries.name: Brace Up
entries: When you gain temporary hit points as a result of using your Brace Up moxie ability, your hound gains the same number of temporary hit points.

entries.name: The Old One-Two
entries: When you use your The Old One-Two moxie ability, your hound can make one or both attacks instead of you.

entries.name: Stick and Move
entries: When you use your Stick and Move moxie ability, your hound can take the Dash action.

subclassFeature.name: Arcanine Bite
entries: At 6th level, your hound's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to non-magical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Coordinated Attack
entries: Also at 6th level, you and your canine companion form a more potent fighting team. When you use the Attack action on your turn, if your hound can see you, it can use its reaction to make a melee attack.

subclassFeature.name: Hound's Best Friend
entries: At 11th level, when a creature deals damage to your hound with an attack, you can use your reaction to make an opportunity attack against that creature if you are within range.

subclassFeature.name: Dire Hound
entries: Beginning at 17th level, you use the statistics for a {@creature dire wolf}, instead of a wolf, for your hound, except that its size remains Medium. These statistics are modified as described in your Brawler's Best Friend feature.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Dread
entries: In your darkest hour you pleaded for the strength to take what you wanted from the world and a dread power took notice. At first, you may have relished the cathartic rush that came with channeling your dread power to claim what you felt you deserved. This pact, however, came with strings attached. In times of distress you hear the entity whispering in the back of your mind, encouraging you to indulge your most base impulses.

subclassFeature.name: Black Magic
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you learn the {@spell blade ward}, {@spell eldritch blast}, and {@spell prestidigitation} cantrips. Constitution is your spellcasting modifier for these spells since you channel the magic of dread powers through your body when you cast them.

In addition, you learn to speak, read, and write one of the following languages of your choice: {@language Abyssal}, {@language Infernal}, or {@language Sylvan}. At the DM's discretion, you may choose another language more appropriate to your dread power.

subclassFeature.name: Dread Hand
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action on your turn to manifest the evidence of your foul pledge. When you do, one of your limbs (often an arm) transmogrifies into a monstrous appearance reminiscent of your dread power for 1 minute.

items: When you roll a 1 on a damage die for an unarmed strike attack you made, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1.
The first time you miss with an unarmed strike attack each turn you can make an additional unarmed strike attack as part of the same action.
Immediately after you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 2 moxie points to make three unarmed strikes as a bonus action.

entries: You must finish a short or long rest before you can use this feature again

entries.name: Dread Powers
entries: A dread power can be any powerful malevolent entity capable of bestowing a portion of its power onto a mortal. Archdemons, fey royalty, ancient liches, and unfathomable intelligences from beyond space and time are all possibilities

subclassFeature.name: Deal with the Devil
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain two {@filter eldritch invocations|optionalfeatures|feature type=ei} of your choice from among those available to the warlock class. When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the invocations you know and replace it with another invocation in which you meet the prerequisites.

subclassFeature.name: Grotesque Growth
entries: At 11th Level, when you use your Dread Hand feature you can choose to grow into a towering misshapen form for one minute. When you do, your size increases by one category—from Medium to Large, for example. If there isn't enough room for you to grow to that size, you grow to the maximum possible size the space will allow. While enlarged in this way, you have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws, your reach becomes 10 feet, and your melee weapon attacks deal {@dice 1d4} extra damage. When the minute is over, you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion} (as described in appendix A of the Player's Handbook).

subclassFeature.name: Fountain of Viscera
entries: At 17th level, you can use an action and expend 6 moxie points to attempt to execute a creature of your choice within reach by burrowing your hand into its body and extracting its innards. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier). On a failure, the creature takes 100 piercing damage. On a success, the creature takes 50 piercing damage instead.

If this damage reduces the target to 0 hit points or less, it immediately dies as you rip a hole through it, creating a stomach-turning fountain of viscera. When this happens, each creature within 30 feet of you who can see you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. A creature who fails the saving throw can make the Wisdom saving throw again at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition frightened} condition early on a success.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Piss & Vinegar
entries: Pugilists in the Piss & Vinegar fight club revel in their reputations as heels. Widely despised for their obscene curses and dirty tricks, these pugilists take pride in their ability to provoke and fight to win at all costs.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: Starting when you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the {@skill Intimidation} skill if you don't have it already.

subclassFeature.name: Salty Salute
entries: Also at 3rd level, you have mastered the art of the enraging insult. You can use a bonus action on your turn to provoke a creature within 60 feet who can see or hear you. That creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes your fisticuff's damage die + your Charisma modifier in psychic damage and has disadvantage on any attack rolls it makes that do not include you as a target before the start of your next turn. For any of your Piss & Vinegar features that require your opponent to make a saving throw, the saving DC is calculated as follows:

subclassFeature.name: Dirty Tricks
entries: Starting at 6th level, you have a few tricks up your sleeve to even the odds when the going gets rough. You can each of these dirty tricks once and regain their use when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Heelstomper
entries: When you deal damage with an unarmed attack, you attempt to slow the creature you hit. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, you gain 1 moxie point (up to your maximum) and its movement speed is halved for one minute.

entries.name: Low Blow
entries: When you deal damage with an unarmed attack you can choose to hit them below the belt. The creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failure, you gain 1 moxie point (up to your maximum) and it is knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Pocket Sand
entries: You can use a bonus action to attempt to blind a creature within 5 feet. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, you gain 1 moxie point (up to your maximum) and it is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Mean Old Cuss
entries: At 11th level, your threats and mean spirited tricks pack an extra punch. When you make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) ability check, you can use your reaction and spend 1 moxie to give yourself advantage on the roll. When a creature makes a saving throw against one of your Piss & Vinegar features, you can use your reaction and spend 1 moxie to give that roll disadvantage.

subclassFeature.name: The Uncouth Art
entries: Starting at 17th level, you gain the ability to offend every creature in the room with minimal effort. When you use your Salty Salute feature, you can choose to target a number of creatures within 60 feet who can see or hear you up to your level in this class instead of a single creature. You gain 1 moxie point (up to your maximum) the first time each creature targeted in this way hits you with an attack before the start of your next turn. You can use this feature again after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Sweet Science
entries: Pugilists who practice the Sweet Science hit hard, fast, and often. This style is sometimes used by fighters who battle for the entertainment of the upper classes, but is just as often practiced in the backalleys and the bars by those whose next breath depends on a knockout.

subclassFeature.name: Cross Counter
entries: Starting when you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you can block the brunt of an attack and launch one of your own in the same fluid motion. You can use your reaction and spend 2 moxie points to reduce the damage of a melee weapon attack made against you by {@dice 1d10} + your Strength modifier + your pugilist level.
If you reduce the damage to 0, you can make an unarmed strike or pugilist weapon attack against a creature within range as part of the same reaction.

subclassFeature.name: One, Two, Three, Floor
entries: At 6th level, when you use your bonus action to use the Old One-Two and hit the same creature with both attacks, you can immediately spend 1 moxie point to make an additional attack with an unarmed strike as part of that bonus action. If you hit, the creature is knocked {@condition prone} in addition to taking damage as normal for your unarmed strike.

subclassFeature.name: Float Like a Butterfly, Sting Like a Bee
entries: At 11th level, when you reduce damage from an attack to 0 and successfully hit an enemy creature using your Cross Counter feature you regain 1 moxie point (up to your maximum).

subclassFeature.name: Knock Out
entries: At 17th level, when you hit with an unarmed strike or pugilist weapon you can spend 1 or more moxie points to try to knock out the opponent instead of dealing damage. Roll {@dice 3d12 + 1d12} for every moxie point spent after the first and add your pugilist level to the result; if the total is equal to or greater than the creature's remaining hit points, it is {@condition unconscious} for 10 minutes.

subclassFeature.name: The Squared Circle
entries: Pugilists who fight in the Squared Circle know you don't have to knock an opponent senseless to get them to submit. Of course, members of the squared circle do beat their opponents senseless, they just know they don't have to.

subclassFeature.name: Groundwork
entries: Starting when you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you gain the following additional moxie features.

entries.name: Compression Lock
entries: When a creature attempts to {@action escape a grapple|phb|break a grapple} with you and succeeds, you can use your reaction and spend 1 moxie point to force the creature to roll again. The creature must use the second result.

entries.name: Quick Pin
entries: When a hostile creature's movement provokes an opportunity attack from you, you can use your reaction and spend 1 moxie point to make a {@action grapple} attack instead of an opportunity attack.

entries.name: To the Mat
entries: You can use a bonus action and spend 1 moxie point to make a grapple attack against a creature within range. If successful, the creature is also knocked {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Meat Shield
entries: At 6th level, when you have an enemy creature {@condition grappled} you gain half cover against all attacks made against you by a creature you are not grappling. When a weapon attack made by a creature you are not grappling misses you, you may use your reaction and spend 1 moxie point to have that creature make the same attack with a new roll against an enemy creature you are grappling.

subclassFeature.name: Heavyweight
entries: At 11th level, you count as one size larger than you are for the purposes of grappling. In addition, you can move your full movement speed when you are dragging or carrying a {@condition grappled} creature your size or smaller.

subclassFeature.name: Clean Finish
entries: At 17th level, your mastery of grappling reaches its peak. While you have a creature {@condition grappled} you gain advantage on all attacks against it. Additionally, when you make an unarmed strike or pugilist weapon attack against a creature you have {@condition grappled} you score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

subclassFeature.name: Whiskey Fist
entries: Pugilists in the Whiskey Fist fight club are the bane of tavern owners throughout the land. There is nothing a Whiskey Fist pugilist likes more than to get a few drinks in his belly and throw down with anyone who dares to give him side eye. Even when wandering ancient ruins or traveling through the wilderness these pugilist always keep a few bottles "just in case".

subclassFeature.name: Drink Like a Demon
entries: Starting when you choose this Fight Club at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to consume a potion or other beverage.
Additionally, when you drink an alcoholic beverage you can use your reaction to trigger your {@classFeature Bloodied but Unbowed|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|3} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Fish In Water
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you drink an alcoholic beverage you can use your reaction to gain 1 moxie point. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Homebrewer
entries: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item brewer's supplies|PHB}. When you finish a rest you can use whatever plant materials and water are at hand and brewer's supplies to create alcoholic beverages. You create {@dice 1d3} when you finish a short rest and {@dice 2d6} when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Hair of the Dog
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you drink an alcoholic beverage you can use your reaction to lose a level of {@condition exhaustion}. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mean Drunk
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you consume an alcoholic beverage you can use your reaction and spend 5 moxie points to enter a drunken frenzy for 1 minute. While in a drunken frenzy, you gain the following benefits:

items: When you use your {@classFeature Haymaker|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|5} feature, you do not gain disadvantage on your weapon attack rolls.
You gain a special reaction you can use each turn to make an opportunity attack. You cannot use your reaction on the same turn you use one of your special reactions.
You ignore the effects of {@condition exhaustion}.

subclassFeature.name: Minotaur in a Glassworker's Shop
entries: Starting at 17th level, add the following benefits to your drunken frenzy.

items: You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
You have advantage on ability checks that add your Strength modifier.
You can move through other creatures. You can use your reaction when you move through a creature one size larger than you or smaller to make a {@action Shove} attack against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Mailed Fist
entries: Most pugilists are armored as heavily as they are armed—which is to say, they're not. But those of certain backgrounds, or from cultures with a heavy emphasis on metalworking such as dwarves, find they brawl better encased in armor. Pugilists in this fight club blend their metallurgical skills with their innate talent for fisticuffs, a combination that grants them scorching strikes and an ironclad resilience.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|PHB} and medium and heavy armor. Additionally, wearing medium and heavy armor does not prevent you from gaining the benefits of your {@classFeature Fisticuffs|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|1} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Fist of Embers
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action and spend 2 moxie points to ignite your fists for 1 minute. While your fists are ignited, you take {@dice 1d6} fire damage at the start of each of your turns and your unarmed strikes deal an additional {@dice 1d6} fire damage. You can choose to end this feature early with no action required by you.

subclassFeature.name: Adamant Will
entries: At 6th level, when a critical hit is made against you while you are wearing medium or heavy armor, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the damage of the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Forged in Fire
entries: Starting at 11th level, you have resistance to fire damage.

In addition, when you take fire damage you can use your reaction to gain temporary hit points equal to the damage taken. You lose all temporary hit points gained from this feature at the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Adamant Body
entries: At 17th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to drop to 1 hit point instead. When you do, you gain temporary hit points equal to twice your pugilist level + your Constitution score and you regain all expended moxie points. You cannot use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Dragonheart
entries: Long ago, a half-dragon trained a group of warriors to aid in her efforts to carve out an empire for herself. She failed but the esoteric techniques she taught these soldiers has been passed down from mentor to student ever since. Unlike joining other fight clubs, pugilists do not become discover these abilities due to temperament or inclination alone. Instead, dragonhearts, as these pugilists are known, dedicate themselves to learning the ancient combat techniques taught by the half-dragon would-be conqueror.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Mien
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you carry yourself with the menacing confidence of dragons. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill if you don't have it already. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.
In addition, you can read, speak, and write {@language Draconic}.

subclassFeature.name: Scales of War
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action on your turn to cause your skin to slough off, temporarily revealing hard scales underneath. When you do, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for 1 minute.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Rebuke
entries: At 6th level, when use your {@classFeature Bloodied but Unbowed|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|3} feature you can choose to exhale a 30-foot cone of elemental energy as part of the same reaction. When you do, you can choose the nature of your breath weapon which determines the type of damage dealt: acid, cold, fire, or lightning.

Each creature in the area of exhalation must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. Creatures who fail this saving throw take {@dice 1d12 + #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Enter Your Pugilist Level!,default=1$#|1d12 + your pugilist level} damage, and half as much on a successful one.

subclassFeature.name: Wings of War
entries: At 11th level, when you use your {@subclassFeature Scales of War|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Dragonheart|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} feature you also sprout wings, giving you a fly speed of 60 feet for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Frightful Presence
entries: At 17th level, as an action you can exude terror to each creature of your choice within 60 feet. Chosen creatures must make a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. On a failed saving throw, the creature becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: King of Beasts
entries: Most pugilists start their path in teeming cities but not all of them stay there. Pugilists in the King of Beasts fight club make their home in the wilderness and discover they are more similar to the streets of major cities than they might have guessed—might makes right in either case. This time living among the beasts of the world changes a pugilist, allowing them to tap into a virile resilience and even learn to take on the many shapes of fauna they've encountered. These pugilists often ally with druids to defend the natural world against those who would abuse it.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Vigor
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, your hit point maximum increases by 6. Whenever you gain a level in this class, your hit point maximum increases by 2.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Shape
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a beast that you have seen before. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Your pugilist level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. At 3rd level, for example, you can transform into any beast that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn't have a flying or swimming speed.

You can stay in a beast shape for a number of hours equal to half your pugilist level (rounded down). You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.
While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

items: Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your alignment, personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature's bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can't use them.

When you transform, you assume the beast's hit points and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in animal form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked {@condition unconscious}.

You can't cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as {@spell call lightning}, that you've already cast.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as {@sense darkvision}, unless your new form also has that sense.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature's shape and size. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

subclassFeature.name: War Shape
entries: At 6th level, you can use a bonus action and expend a use of your {@subclassFeature Wild Shape|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|King of Beasts|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} to take on a war shape for 1 minute. When you do, choose one beast you can transform into using your Wild Shape feature.
While you are in your war shape, you combine features of your normal appearance with those of the chosen beast and you gain the following benefits for the duration:

items: You gain any special senses and movement speeds the beast has.
If the beast has any natural weapon attacks that deal piercing or slashing damage, you can choose to deal that damage type when you deal damage with an unarmed strike.
Your unarmed strikes deal an additional {@dice 1d4} damage.
If the beast is any size category smaller than you, you can choose to reduce your size by one category (from Medium to Small, for example) until your war shape ends.
If the beast is any size category larger than you, you can choose to increase your size by one category (from Medium to Large, for example) until your war shape ends.
You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) ability checks.

subclassFeature.name: Cornered but Not Caught
entries: At 11th level, when you use your {@classFeature Bloodied but Unbowed|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|3} feature you can choose to also use this feature. If you do, you regain hit points equal to your Constitution modifier at the start of each of your turns for the next minute. This effect ends early if you are reduced to 0 hit points. You can use this feature again after you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Beast at Heart
entries: Starting at 17th level, you can use your {@subclassFeature Wild Shape|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|King of Beasts|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} feature twice, regaining both uses when you finish a short or long rest.

When you use your {@subclassFeature Wild Shape|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|King of Beasts|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} feature, you can choose to expend both uses. When you do, you can choose a beast with a challenge rating up to 5.

When you use your {@subclassFeature War Shape|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|King of Beasts|SterlingVermin:Patreon|6} feature, you can choose to expend both uses. When you do, you choose up to three beasts and gain the special senses and movement speeds of each beast (using the highest of each movement speed if multiple chosen beasts have the same kind of movement speed). Additionally, the additional damage dealt by your unarmed strikes increases to {@dice 1d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Street Saint
entries: Pugilists rise above the adversity they face. Those known as Street Saints do so with the aid of their deep and abiding faith in the gods. These pugilists have had their convictions tested and come out the other side with their righteous resolve only strengthened. They fight to make the world a better place. They fight because they believe their god has called them to. They fight because wherever corruption is allowed to exist, justice cannot flourish.

entries.subclassFeature: Channel Divinity: Fists of Faith|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3
Channel Divinity: Grace of the Gods|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you choose this fight club at 3rd level, you gain the ability to channel divine energy directly from your deity, using that energy to fuel magical effects. You start with two such effects: {@subclassFeature Channel Divinity: Fists of Faith|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} and {@subclassFeature Channel Divinity: Grace of the Gods|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3}.

When you use your Channel Divinity, you choose which effect to create. You must then finish a short or long rest to use your Channel Divinity again. Some Channel Divinity effects require saving throws. When you use such an effect from this class, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier.
Beginning at 11th level, you can use your Channel Divinity twice between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Fists of Faith
entries: You use a bonus action and offer up your hands to the will of the divine. For the next minute, your unarmed strikes score a critical hit on a result of 19 or 20.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Grace of the Gods
entries: As a bonus action, you offer a prayer up to the gods and their divine protection surrounds you. You gain {@dice 1d10} + your pugilist level in temporary hit points. While you have any temporary hit points from this ability, you have resistance to all damage. You lose all temporary hit points granted by this ability after 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Lay on Hands
entries: Also at 3rd level, your blessed touch can heal wounds. You have a pool of healing power that replenishes when you take a long rest. With that pool, you can restore a total number of hit points equal to your pugilist level x 5.
As an action, you can touch a creature and draw power from the pool to restore a number of hit points to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in your pool.

Alternatively, you can expend 5 hit points from your pool of healing to cure the target of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting it. You can cure multiple diseases and neutralize poisons with a single use of Lay on Hands, expending hit points separately for each one.
This feature has no effect on undead and constructs.

subclassFeature.name: Hallowed Hands
entries: At 6th level, when you deal damage to a creature with an unarmed strike you can expend a number of hit points from your {@subclassFeature Lay on Hands|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} feature up to your level in this class to deal additional radiant damage equal to the hit points expended. This damage is doubled if the creature is a fiend or undead. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Ravaged but Resolute
entries: At 11th level, when you use your {@classFeature Bloodied but Unbowed|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|3} feature you can choose to also use this feature. If you do, the pool of hit points your {@subclassFeature Lay on Hands|Pugilist|SterlingVermin|Street Saint|SterlingVermin:Patreon|3} feature grants you is refilled to its maximum. You can use this feature again after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Resilience
entries: Starting at 17th level, as a bonus action on your turn you can lend your spiritual mettle to your allies. For the next minute, you and each friendly creature within 30 feet gain resistance to all damage. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Astral-bound Soul
entries: Your innate magic is channeled through the planar pools which connect many of the planes of existence to the astral plane. Your soul has been split in two, with the majority of its essence - the "anchor"-bound to the astral plane. Many such souls never awaken their power, but through intense training, a near-death experience, or other elevating event, you have gained awareness and control of this flexible magic source.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your magic allows you to connect space, even in others' minds and across planar boundaries. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Anchor
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you gain control of the astral magic channeled through your soul anchor.

A silvery cord extends from between your shoulder blades and trails behind you, fading to invisibility after 1 foot. This cord is your tether to your astral anchor. Should you travel to the astral plane, such as by the {@spell astral projection} spell, this cord exists in addition to the astral tether to your body. If the cord is cut - something that can happen only when an effect specifically states that it does - your soul and anchor are separated, and your astral-bound soul features are lost. A {@spell greater restoration} or wish spell can restore the link to your soul anchor.

As a bonus action, you can channel magical energy through your astral anchor. For the next minute, when you cast a spell, you can create an invisible, protective field of psychic energy around yourself. This field grants you temporary hit points equal to the spell's level (1 if the spell is a cantrip) + your Charisma modifier, which are lost if they remain when this feature's duration elapses. You have resistance to psychic damage while you have any of these temporary hit points.
Once you have used this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Dire Retreat
entries: Also at 1st level, your soul retreats into your anchor when you are slain, and its magic preserves your body.

While you are tethered to your astral anchor, whenever you die, your body gains the effects of the {@spell gentle repose} spell, and your soul becomes contained within your astral anchor. Any attempt to dispel {@spell gentle repose} cast in this way, or to call your soul away from your astral anchor, fails unless you choose to be affected or the source of the attempt succeeds a Charisma check against your spell save DC.

subclassFeature.name: Siphon Sorcery
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can draw upon your anchor's well of sorcerous power in addition to your own. When you spend 2 or more sorcery points during a turn, you can immediately use your reaction to regain 1 sorcery point.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Protection
entries: Starting at 14th level, your astral anchor protects you in response to dire threats.

Immediately after you are {@condition incapacitated} or knocked {@condition unconscious}, you can choose to gain the benefits of the {@spell Otiluke's resilient sphere|PHB|resilient sphere} spell, with the following changes: it doesn't require concentration, the sphere is resistant to all damage instead of immune, it has 15 AC, and it has 4 hit points for each of your Sorcerer levels. When all of these hit points are lost, the spell ends, and you take any remaining damage. If a creature touches the sphere, you can choose to end the spell, whether you are conscious or not. You can also choose to end it on your turn (no action required by you).
Once you have used this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Transport
entries: Starting at 18th level, your astral anchor has gained enough fortitude to support transporting your physical form. When you cast a spell, you can expend 3 sorcery points to teleport up to 30 feet to a point you can see before casting the spell. You also gain a short burst of power in the process, increasing the damage of the spell. The damage increase equals half your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Collective Mind
entries: You have a neural link to the central consciousness of a hive, colony, or some other collective. Those with this link have some relation to these entities; be it an integrated ancestor, indoctrination, cloning, or otherwise. Their link allows these sorcerers to use the reconnaissance and communication available to their collective.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your magic comes from the seemingly boundless knowledge and resources of your collective. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Collective Genetics
entries: When you awaken to this origin at 1st level, choose one collective from the Collective Genetics table. Your choice determines certain traits of drones you summon with your Summon Drone feature.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. climb & 20 ft. burrow

items.name: Sense:
entries: {@sense tremorsense|MM} 60 ft.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. fly

items.name: Keen Sight:
entries: The drone has advantage on {@skill Perception} checks requiring sight.

items.name: Sense:
entries: telepathy 120 ft., shares its host's senses

items.name: Symbiosis:
entries: The drone can't attack, and it dies if it is separated from its host for 1 minute.

items.name: Attach to Host:
entries: As an action, the drone embeds itself into a willing or {@condition unconscious} creature within 5 feet of it. While embedded, the drone is {@condition unconscious} and is indistinguishable from its host. The drone is ejected to the nearest unoccupied space if its host has 0 hit points.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. swim

items.name: Aquatic:
entries: The drone can breathe air or water.

subclassFeature.name: Summon Drone
entries: Also at 1st level, you can summon a collective drone to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you as an action, which lasts until it dies or you dismiss it by using your bonus action. You describe the drone's appearance, which must accommodate its features, size and traits.

dataCreature.name: Collective Drone
languages: Understands its summoner but can't speak

trait.name: Homogeneity.
entries: The attack drone gains traits based on its summoner's {@subclassFeature Collective Genetics|Variant Sorcerer|VariantSorcerer_By_devikyn|Collective|VariantSorcerer_By_devikyn|1}  feature.

In combat, drones share your initiative and take the {@action Dodge} action, avoiding any danger. Drones add your proficiency bonus to their {@skill Investigation} and {@skill Perception} checks. You can use your action to see and hear through a drone's senses as long as you are on the same plane, or to return from using the drone's senses to yours.
You can have a number of drones at a time equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Consult Collective
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can spend 10 minutes in commune with your collective, as long as you are on the same plane of existence to inquire about one event, object or piece of information that you know. At the DM's discretion, the collective can share its knowledge as it relates to your inquiry via a truthful reply.

subclassFeature.name: Stream of Consciousness
entries: Starting at 14th level, your consciousness becomes a permanent part of your collective, which can produce a new body for you should yours perish.
If you die, you return to life 24 hours after death. You reform within 1 mile of your place of death at a point chosen by the DM. Your equipment remains where you died, if it wasn't destroyed.

subclassFeature.name: Regal Command
entries: Starting at 18th level, the regal presence of your collective mind can be implanted into the conscious of another, weaving into their psyche and inducting them into your collective.

As an action, you can touch a non-hostile creature, which must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or regard you as family. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours and is aware that you attempted to manipulate it. A {@spell greater restoration} spell ends the effect.

subclassFeature.name: Gloom-touched
entries: Gloom-touched sorcerers are those who are tainted with demonic magic. These are most commonly descendants of creatures doomed to Hades by a curse, but some may also be born by ritual, a desperate pact, or some other demonic encounter. These sorcerers have magical abilities warped in dark and deranged ways, allowing them to capture and manipulate the souls of fallen creatures. Due to their demonic nature, gloom-touched sorcerers can often be subject to scorn or even violence.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Calling upon demonic magic is a simple task for you, with your hellish origin. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Extraction
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you can trap a fallen soul in a state of limbo, temporarily retaining it.

You can use your action to touch a creature that died within the last minute. If the creature's challenge rating is equal to or lower than your sorcerer level, you shackle its soul; the soul takes on an insubstantial, but corporeal form, which hovers near you and follows you for up to 8 hours, after which it is freed and moves on. A soul so retained cannot be resurrected until it is freed.

When you use this feature, you can ask the soul one question. If you do, the soul must make a Charisma saving throw - using its creature statistics - against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the soul is compelled to answer truthfully with whatever detail it knew in life. Otherwise, it is free to answer as it would normally.
You can retain a limited number of souls at any given time. This number equals your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Hellish Vision
entries: Also at 1st level, you gain the ability to see through the lens of hades, a vision devoid of color and detail which inflicts apathy upon its beholder.

As a bonus action, you can begin or end your hellish vision. Hellish vision functions as {@sense darkvision}, extends to your entire range of sight, and cannot be impeded by magical darkness. You cannot see color while using hellish vision, only shades of gray.

While your hellish vision is active, a wave of apathy washes over you, imposing disadvantage on your attack rolls and ability checks. You can suspend this apathy for 1 minute by using your action to drain energy from one of your retained souls. Doing so immediately frees the soul.

subclassFeature.name: Selfish Sacrifice
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use a fragment of a trapped soul as a seed to replenish your own vitality.

When damage reduces you to 0 hit points but doesn't outright kill you, you can use a retained soul to make a Constitution saving throw (DC 10 or half of the damage, whichever is higher). On a successful save, you are instead reduced to 1 hit point. The soul is freed whether you succeed or fail.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Attractor
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your magic to quickly draw the souls of others to you, even at a distance.

You can use your Soul Extraction feature at a range of 30 feet, and you can expend 1 sorcery point to use the feature as a reaction when a creature other than you is reduced to 0 hit points; if you do, you also regain hit points equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Barter Souls
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can call forth a fiend to create a contract in exchange for souls.

By spending 1 minute in concentration (as if concentrating on a spell) and choosing any number of your currently retained souls, you can call forth a fiend from its native plane. Based on the number of souls offered, a creature appears in an unoccupied space of the DM's choice within 30 feet of you. Consult the Barter Souls Summoning table to find the creatures you can summon.

The fiend remains under control of the DM at all times. It offers a contract: assistance with a single task or goal in exchange for the amount of trapped souls shown in the Barter Souls Summoning table. You describe this task or goal in up to two sentences, which the fiend uses to forge the contract and immediately receive its payment. The fiend interprets your contract in good faith, and it executes a given contract to the best of its ability; however, it does not treat you as an ally for purposes beyond the calling of its contract, and its contractual obligations end if you die.

The fiend is likely to look for ways it can extract further compensation from you, and is capable of offering further deals. Once its contracts are fulfilled, or if the fiend is reduced to 0 hit points, it returns to its place of origin.

subclassFeature.name: Gravitational Magic
entries: You have the ability to sense and interact with the gravitational forces inherent in reality around you. Your magic allows you to manipulate these physics, but also confuses your psyche; a result of interacting with the natural forces of the world in ways your body and mind cannot properly decipher.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your natural control of gravity allows you to harness your magic's unique properties into easily manifested forms. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Extradimensional Mark
entries: Your sorcerous origin's abilities leave lasting and sometimes unpredictable impressions on you, altering some aspects of your behavior. Choose any number of extradimensional marks below, or roll any number of {@dice (#$prompt_number:min=1, title=Enter a Number!, default=123$#)d4|d4s} to determine your marks.

rows: Air sometimes feels solid to you. It's stifling.
You can feel the blood circulating through your veins.
Pockets of altered gravity form randomly around you, causing oddities like your clothes hanging heavily, your hair floating, or randomly losing your equilibrium.
Your balance is exceptionally poor; you are clumsy and your gait is unstable.

subclassFeature.name: Gravity Well
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you can manipulate the local effects of gravity around creatures.

As a bonus action, choose a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you. An unwilling creature can make a Charisma saving throw to avoid being affected; if it succeeds, it becomes immune to this feature for 1 minute. On a failed saving throw, choose one of the following options, which affects creatures in a 5-foot radius of the target (including the target) until the end of your next turn:

items.name: Increase Gravity.
entries: Increased pressure makes everything heavier around the target, reducing each affected creature's speed by 10 feet.

items.name: Decrease Gravity.
entries: Decreasing gravitational influence around the target makes everything around it lighter, increasing each affected creature's speed by 10 feet and halving the weight of all affected creatures and objects.

You can use your bonus action on your subsequent turns to extend this feature's duration until the end of your next turn. If you use this feature again - choosing a different target or a different option - while its effect is already active, the current effect ends.

subclassFeature.name: Unfettered Domain
entries: Also at 1st level, objects and equipment that you carry, or those contained entirely within a 5-foot radius of you, weigh half of their normal weight, unless another effect halves their weight already.

subclassFeature.name: Limber Force
entries: Starting at 6th level, you become inherently able to amplify your kinetic force with magic, and you learn to create a small, localized field of dense gravity.

When you deal damage to a creature with a sorcerer spell, you can push or pull the creature up to 10 feet. You can spend sorcery points to increase the distance that the creature is pushed or pulled by 10 feet for each sorcery point spent.

Also, when you are attacked by a source within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to create a field of rejecting gravity, encapsulating and slowing the strike. You gain resistance to the attack's damage, and if the attacker is a creature, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature cannot make attacks until the start of its next turn. Once you have used this reaction, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Acceleration
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can harness control of gravity when you use magic, allowing you a short burst of gravity-induced acceleration.

If you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, you can spend 1 sorcery point to {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} as a bonus action. When you do, any speeds you have are doubled until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Crushing Influence
entries: Starting at 18th level, your mastery of gravity allows you to intensify others' gravitational pull to such a level that those around them are crushed under the pressure.

As an action, you can spend 2 sorcery points and choose a point within 60 feet of you that you can see. Until the start of your next turn, a 20-ft radius sphere of crushing gravitational force envelops the area.

Any creature contained fully within the area of this sphere that moves more than 5 feet or starts its turn there must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone} and have its speed set to 0 until the start of its next turn. Once a creature succeeds on its saving throw against this effect, it is immune to the effect until the start of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguinary Heritage
entries: You have a taste for blood. Whether this trait is hereditary, gifted, or magical in nature, you can use your magic to draw out the essence of your foes and consume it, and you have an insatiable urge to do just that. Many such sorcerers can trace their abilities back to a powerful vampire, a bloodthirsty fiend, or a curse.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: The intense bloodthirst in your veins manifests in the form of magical aptitude. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Lifestealer
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, your life-draining magic soothes your victim and replenishes your vitality.

When you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher that deals necrotic damage, you regain hit points equal to half of the damage dealt to one of the targets, in addition to any health the spell restores.

In addition, when you deal necrotic damage to a creature with a spell, it does not feel pain from the necrotic damage, and it must succeed a Wisdom ability check against your spell save DC to discern that it has taken damage.

subclassFeature.name: Shallow Youth
entries: Also at 1st level, your magic retains an imprint of your physical state when you first awakened to it, which can be called upon by feeding.

Whenever you regain hit points by dealing necrotic damage, you can cause your physical appearance to transform such that your age appears to be the same as when you first awakened to this Sorcerous Origin. For example, wrinkles may disappear, your posture may improve, and your hair may change in color and texture. These effects last for 24 hours, at which point you revert back to your natural appearance.

subclassFeature.name: False Dependence
entries: Starting at 6th level, victims of your magic feel a temporary need to depend on you.

You can use your bonus action and spend 2 sorcery points to choose a creature within 60 feet of you that is charmed by you or who has taken damage from one of your spells this turn. That creature must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or be afflicted with Dependence, a disease that causes it to have disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks against you for 10 minutes. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw each minute, ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Bathe in Blood
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can draw out your own blood and mix it into your spells, rending your enemies with sharp, lacerating magic.
When you deal damage to a creature with a sorcerer spell, you can reduce your hit points by an amount no greater than your sorcerer level to deal the same amount of slashing damage to that creature.

subclassFeature.name: True Dependence
entries: Starting at 18th level, your disease's potency increases, temporarily enthralling your victims.

Any creature afflicted with Dependence treats you as a close friend for the disease's duration. It won't risk its life for you or fight for you, unless it was already inclined to do so. It grants you favors and gifts it would offer to a close friend. You know the afflicted creature's emotional state, surface thoughts, and location relative to you at all times, as long as you are on the same plane of existence.
When the disease ends, the creature doesn't know why it held you in such high regard.

subclassFeature.name: Soulknife
entries: Soulknives are initiates of an ancient technique that uses magic to awaken the mind. These sorcerers are trained to be assassins and spies, as their abilities are difficult to discern and allow them to act rapidly. With their ability to harness both magical and mental energy, they can create lethal weapons and strike with deadly precision.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your psychic awakening affords you a repertoire of spells useful for manipulating and wearing down the mind. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Martial Training
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with light armor, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers and shortswords.
Additionally, your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Focus
entries: Also at 1st level, you can construct weapons out of mental energy. These weapons deal damage directly to the minds of others, and act as a conduit for your spells.

As a bonus action, you can create a weapon that flows with mental energy, a Soul Focus, in one of your free hands. This weapon takes the form of a {@item dagger|phb}, a {@item longsword|phb}, a {@item rapier|phb} or a {@item shortsword|phb} (your choice), using the same statistics as the chosen weapon except that it does psychic damage instead of its normal damage type. You can never be disarmed of your Soul Focus unless you choose to be. You can use your Soul Focus as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells. If you are {@condition unconscious} or you let go of your Soul Focus on a turn, it disappears at the end of the turn.
At certain levels in this class, you gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls made using your Soul Focus: +1 at 6th level and +2 at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Blinkstrike
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use mental energy to travel through a momentary rift, cutting through your foe's defense.

You can use your bonus action and spend 2 sorcery points to teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see and then make one weapon attack with your Soul Focus. At 14th level, this attack deals an extra {@dice 1d8} force damage on a hit.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Also at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Projected Blades
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can create a projection of psychic weaponry, which strikes everything in a small area.

As a bonus action, you can expend 3 sorcery points to choose a point within 30 feet of you. You can make a weapon attack against each creature within 5 feet of the chosen point, using your soul focus, as though you were standing in the space. Each time you hit a creature with one of these attacks, you can spend 1 sorcery point to deal an additional {@damage 1d10} psychic damage to the target.

subclassFeature.name: Cut the Psyche
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can overload a creature's mind when you strike it, causing you to disappear from its sight.

When you hit a creature with your Soul Focus, you can spend 3 sorcery points to force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature can't see or hear you by any means until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You know one spell of your choice of each spell level in the Metal Magic feature, which doesn't count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Time Domain
entries: Deities that can influence the flow of time are few and far between in the Forgotten Realms, as 'time' is a great, universal constant that mortals can only begin to grasp. Clerics that worship a such a deity can, if only for a brief instant, channel their divine powers to stop their enemies in stasis and grant their allies an amazing alacrity.
At each indicated cleric level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons.

subclassFeature.name: Glimpse of the Future
entries: From 1st level, your prayer gives you a glimpse of the future, allowing you to forsee certain events. You cannot be surprised as long as you are conscious, and you add your Wisdom modifier to your initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Delayment
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to delay the actions of others.

As a reaction to a creature taking an action or bonus action within 15 feet of you, you can cause that action to happen at the end of your next turn or until your concentration ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell).

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Rollback
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to bring back a part of your power. As a bonus action, you touch your holy symbol, utter a prayer, and regain a spell slot you expended on this turn. The spell slot regained cannot be higher than a 5th-level spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Elongate
entries: At 17th level, you are gifted with the power to become a constant in time. As an action, you can cause a loop in time that constantly rewinds your body's metabolism and aging.

Ending the effect can be done with an action, however, the flow of time corrects itself immediately, and any time that passed during the rewind hits you at once. While the effect is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You do not need to eat, drink or breathe.
You don't need to sleep.
You do not age, and can't be aged magically.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Predict
entries: Also at 17th level, you can cast the {@spell Foresight} spell once per long rest.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most dwarves are lawful, believing firmly in the benefits of a well-ordered society. They tend toward good as well, with a strong sense of fair play and a belief that everyone deserves to share in the benefits of a just order.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Traveler's Step
entries: Your base walking speed is 35 ft., however wearing heavy armor will reduce your speed to 25 ft.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Trade Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Cartographer's Tools|phb}, Land Vehicles, or {@item Painter's Supplies|phb}.

entries.name: Expert Cunning (The Art of Bullshittery)
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Persuasion}, {@skill Performance}, or {@skill Deception}

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Dwarvish. Dwarvish is full of hard consonants and guttural sounds, and those characteristics spill over into whatever other language a dwarf might speak.

entries.name: Well Travelled
entries: You gain an additional language proficiency of your choice.

entries.name: A Society of Backpackers
entries: Travelers, merchants, and storytellers there are many professions a dwarf may pick up when they leave the underground and choose to live life above it all. Road dwarves have abandoned the smithing and stonecutting techniques of their subterran bretheren but make up for it in skills that help their new trades.

entries.name: Above Ground Dwarven Culture
entries: Dwarven Culture is almost always tied to heritage, whose house is in control of what branch of dwarven society. Living in mountains and beneath the earth is almost second nature to dwarves, so where do road dwarves fit into this? Road dwarves are the revels, the rogues, people who wanted to see more of the world and move away from the deadlocked ideals of tradition. Road dwarves literally take to the road, finding their way along the path as travelers. Many take the chance to become merchants seeking fortune, others begin caravan companies, and even more become wanderlust adventurers.

entries.name: Oh To Be a Road Dwarf
entries: Spotting a dwarf without armor above ground means you have most likely run into a road dwarf, they have long since abandoned smithing as a profession (though some may choose to relearn) and mostly prefer lighter clothing and weaponry to accomodate their vagabond lifestyles. Their time travelling have put a much lighter step in their heels and thus road dwarves whether on cart, mount, or foot seem to move about much more quickly and frequently than the average dwarf. Being more open to new things means it's not uncommon to spot a road dwarf bard recounting their adventures in a tavern or a master marksman and their trusty heavy crossbow.

Kingdoms rich in ancient grandeur, halls carved into the roots of mountains, the echoing of picks and hammers in deep mines and blazing forges, a commitment to clan and tradition, and a burning hatred of goblins and orcs-these common threads unite all dwarves.

entries.name: Short and Stout
entries: Bold and hardy, dwarves are known as skilled warriors, miners, and workers of stone and metal. Though they stand well under 5 feet tall, dwarves are so broad and compact that they can weigh as much as a human standing nearly two feet taller. Their courage and endurance are also easily a match for any of the larger folk.
Dwarven skin ranges from deep brown to a paler hue tinged with red, but the most common shades are light brown or deep tan, like certain tones of earth.
Their hair, worn long but in simple styles, is usually black, gray, or brown, though paler dwarves often have red hair. Male dwarves value their beards highly and groom them carefully.

entries.name: Long Memory, Long Grudges
entries: Dwarves can live to be more than 400 years old, so the oldest living dwarves often remember a very different world. For example, some of the oldest dwarves living in Citadel Felbarr (in the world of the Forgotten Realms) can recall the day, more than three centuries ago, when orcs conquered the fortress and drove them into an exile that lasted over 250 years. This longevity grants them a perspective on the world that shorter-lived races such as humans and halflings lack.

Dwarves are solid and enduring like the mountains they love, weathering the passage of centuries with stoic endurance and little change. They respect the traditions of their clans, tracing their ancestry back to the founding of their most ancient strongholds in the youth of the world, and don't abandon those traditions lightly. Part of those traditions is devotion to the gods of the dwarves, who uphold the dwarven ideals of industrious labor, skill in battle, and devotion to the forge.

Individual dwarves are determined and loyal, true to their word and decisive in action, sometimes to the point of stubbornness. Many dwarves have a strong sense of justice, and they are slow to forget wrongs they have suffered. A wrong done to one dwarf is a wrong done to the dwarf's entire clan, so what begins as one dwarf's hunt for vengeance can become a full-blown clan feud.

entries.name: Clans and Kingdoms
entries: Dwarven kingdoms stretch deep beneath the mountains where the dwarves mine gems and precious metals and forge items of wonder. They love the beauty and artistry of precious metals and fine jewelry, and in some dwarves this love festers into avarice. Whatever wealth they can't find in their mountains, they gain through trade. They dislike boats, so enterprising humans and halflings frequently handle trade in dwarven goods along water routes. Trustworthy members of other races are welcome in dwarf settlements, though some areas are off limits even to them.

The chief unit of dwarven society is the clan, and dwarves highly value social standing. Even dwarves who live far from their own kingdoms cherish their clan identities and affiliations, recognize related dwarves, and invoke their ancestors' names in oaths and curses. To be clanless is the worst fate that can befall a dwarf.
Dwarves in other lands are typically artisans, especially weaponsmiths, armorers, and jewelers. Some become mercenaries or bodyguards, highly sought after for their courage and loyalty.

entries.name: Gods, Gold, and Clan
entries: Dwarves who take up the adventuring life might be motivated by a desire for treasure-for its own sake, for a specific purpose, or even out of an altruistic desire to help others.
